message_1: A quantum computer is made of three qubits, with possible states $\left| 000 \right\rangle$, $\left| 100 \right\rangle$, $\left| 010 \right\rangle$, $\left| 110 \right\rangle$, $\left| 001 \right\rangle$, $\left| 101 \right\rangle$, $\left| 011 \right\rangle$, or $\left| 111 \right\rangle$. After performing a quantum operation, you measure the probability distribution of the output states and obtain the following results: $P\left(000\right) = 0.01$, $P\left(100\right) = 0.03$, $P\left(010\right) = 0.4$, $P\left(110\right) = 0.2$, $P\left(001\right) = 0.01$, $P\left(101\right) = 0.05$, $P\left(011\right) = 0.2$, and $P\left(111\right) = 0.08$. Use quantum state tomography to find the density matrix of the final state of the quantum computer.
message_2:
To find the density matrix of the final state of the quantum computer, we first need to express the final state as a linear combination of the basis states. Since we have the probabilities for each basis state, we can write the final state as:

$\left|\psi\right\rangle = \sqrt{0.01}\left|000\right\rangle + \sqrt{0.03}\left|100\right\rangle + \sqrt{0.4}\left|010\right\rangle + \sqrt{0.2}\left|110\right\rangle + \sqrt{0.01}\left|001\right\rangle + \sqrt{0.05}\left|101\right\rangle + \sqrt{0.2}\left|011\right\rangle + \sqrt{0.08}\left|111\right\rangle$

Now, we can find the density matrix $\rho$ by taking the outer product of the state vector with itself:

$\rho = \left|\psi\right\rangle\left\langle\psi\right|$

Calculating the outer product, we get:

$\rho = \begin{pmatrix}
0.01 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0.03 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0.4 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0.2 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0.01 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0.05 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0.2 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0.08
\end{pmatrix}$

So, the density matrix of the final state of the quantum computer is:

$\rho = \begin{pmatrix}
0.01 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0.03 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0.4 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
